text:
Centre Street (left) & Park Row (right), northward from a point on Nassau Street and across Frankfort Street. The Tryon Row Buildings were replaced by the Stats Zeitung Building, and which in turn was replaced by the Municipal Building. Note the spire of the St. Andrews R. C. Church across same. On the right is the 5 story building that housed Tammany Hall until it's acquisition in 1868 by the Sun. This structure is at the S. E. corner of Nassau and Frankfort Street's. The dark building beyond is Frenchs Hotel (Pulitzer Building site).

Early 1860's

American Studio, photo
87 Nassau Street

Gift of the Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RIGHTS UNKNOWN
title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row

text:
Centre Street (left) and Park Row, northward, showing the Staats 2eitung Building. Upon this site rose the present Municipal Building. On the left is the fire engine house in City Hall Park, separated by Chambers Street from the row of buildings, upon which site the Hall of Records was erected. Park Row on the right, appears prior to the erection of tho Third
Avenue 'E1.'
1870
Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row

text:
Park Row, east side, south from and including Spruce Street, to and including Broadway. Also shown is Nassau Street, east side, south from and including Spruce, to and including Fulton Streets. The view shows the New York Times Building, at the intersection of Park Row, and Nassau Street, and the rear of the General Post Office on Mail Street. In the foreground is seen a portion of City Hall Park, while in the background, and at the termination of Park Row, is seen St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel.

About 1870.

Brown Brothers.
title: Manhattan: Park Row - Spruce Street

text:
Park Row, at the intersection of Centre Street. This view also includes the former Hall of Records and the Staats-Zeitung Building.

About 1876.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Park Row - Centre Street

text:
(1)
Nassau Street, east side, south from and including Frankfort, to and including Spruce Streets.
About 1921.

Paul Thompson.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

(2)
The same as seen from City Hall Park and showing the Tribune Building in its entity. The adjoining building, prominently shown in No. 1 is the former Tammany Hall.

About 1880.

Gift of H.D. Jewett.

Centre Street, north from Park Row.

About 1885.

Brown Brothers.
title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row

text:
Nassau Street, east side, from Spruce (right) to Frank-fort (left) Street's, showing structures lining Printing House Square, as photographed from City Hall Park. The Tribune Building is the dominant feature with the clock tower. On the left is Frenchs Hotel. This will be re-placed shortly with the Pulitzer (World) Building. The 5 story Sun Building separates these items. On the margins, left and right respectively, are the City Hall, and the Times Building (under construction).

Winter 1888-9

Thru New York Historical Society

Nassau Street, east side, from Spruce (right) to Frank-fort (left) Street's, showing the buildings identified with this locale, Printing House Square. From right to left, these are, the Times Building (erected 1888), the Tribune Building (erected 1870's), the Sun Building (Chas. A. Dana became editor in 1868 and transfered here), and the Pulitzer (World) Building (erected 1888-9). At the left margin appears a portion of the City Hall and the Brooklyn Bridge train shed. The trees in the fore-ground are in City Hell Park.

About 1891

Thru New York Historical Society

Centre Street, east side, north from Park Row. This view shows the Staats-Zeitung Building.
About 1895.

Brown Brothers.
title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row

text:
170 Nassau Street, at the S.E. corner of Frankfort Street. (Park Row and Nassau Street, intersect at this point.) This building was the original headquarters of Tammany Hall, which moved from here to East 14th Street, in 1867, and later to the east side of Union Square. Charles A Dana edited the New York Sun while it occupied this building.

About 1900.

Wurts Brothers.

Nassau Street, east side, at Spruce Street. The view also shows Spruce Street, south side, at Nassau Street. In the foreground is a portion of Printing House Square, with a statue of Benjamin Franklin. On the left is the old Tribune Building and the former Times Building is on the right.

About 1905.

Brown Brothers.

Park Row, north from Spruce Street and showing prominently the Municipal Building (Centre Street and Park Row) under construction. On the left is City Hall Park; a rear view of the 5-story City Court and the new Hall of Records. The enclosed bridge structure provided access to the Brooklyn Bridge and its transportation facilities.

About 1910

Ewing Galloway
title: Manhattan: Park Row - Spruce Street

text:
Centre Street & Park Row (convergence), showing the Municipal Building under construction in View 1, and completed in View 2. The photographers vantage point in both instances is City Hall Park. Note the enclosed over-pass to the Brooklyn Bridge at the right.

No. 1: 1911
2: Sept., 1914

George L. Balgue
title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row

text:
Centre Street & Park Row (convergence), showing the Municipal Building under construction in View 1, and completed in View 2. The photographers vantage point in both instances is City Hall Park. Note the enclosed over-pass to the Brooklyn Bridge at the right.

No. 1: 1911
2: Sept., 1914

George L. Balgue
title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row

text:
Centre Street and Park Row convergence, northward across Chambers Street, showing the Municipal Building under construction.

Park Row is on the right and has the "El" line there upon. Chambers Street is at the left and separates the new Hall of Records from the fire engine house in City Hall Park. Across the top are two of Manhattan's great bridges, the Manhattan, and the Williamsburg.

Gift of Urbrock Collection
International News

1912
title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row

text:
Park Row and Center Street, showing the Municipal Building, 24 stories high and an elevation of 580 feet, located at that site.

1913.

Copyright by,
Irving Underhill,
title: Manhattan: Park Row - Centre Street

text:

At the intersection of Park Row, and Centre Street, showing the Second and Third Aves., Elevated Brooklyn Bridge Station Extension over Park Row to City Hall.
May 3, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)Park Row and William Street, showing elevated Station.
August 192I.

George Balgue,

title: Manhattan: Park Row - Centre Street

text:
Centre Street, north from Park Row. On the west side of Centre Street, appears the present Hall of Records. The Municipal Building is shown on the right.

About 1925.

Brown Brothers.
title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row

text:
Park Row, north from and including Spruce Street. The view shows (from left to right), the N. Y. City Hall, Hall of Records, the Municipal Building, the N. Y. Herold Building, the Pulitzer (World) Building, Tribune Building and the Potter (Times) Building. Bridge shown in the foreground, across Park Row, is an extension from the Brooklyn Bridge Station of the Second and Third Aves., Elevated Lines.

About 1927.

New York Edison Co.
title: Manhattan: Park Row - Spruce Street

text:
(1) A general view, southwest from the Municipal Building, at the intersection of Park Row and Centre Street, showing the New Jersey Shore, and the Hudson River in the background. In the centre is the Woolworth Building, (233 Broadway, between Barclay Street and Park Place). Broadway, is shown from and including Park Place, to and including Murray Street, with a portion of City Hall Park in the foreground.

May 27, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from a different angle.

May 27, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

title: General view - Centre Street - Southwest.

text:
A general view southward from atop the Municipal Building at Park Row and Centre Street, showing the tall structures forming the well known Wall Street outline. The three most prominent are: the 60 Wall Street Tower (under construction in No. 1), the Farmer Bank-City Trust Company Building, and the Bank of Manhattan.

June 12, 1931
Views 2 and 3: June 23, 1933

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Centre Street - South. [Manhattan: Park Row - Centre Street ; Municipal Building ; Bank of Manhattan ; City Bank-Farmers Trust Company ; 60 Wall Street Tower ; New York Telephone Company.]

text:
(1) A general view, northeast from the Municipal Building, at the intersection of Park Row and Centre Street, showing the Second and Third Aves., Elevated Lines in the foreground; at the right is part of the Manhattan Bridge, (extending from Canal Street, at third Ave., Manhattan, to Flatbush and Myrtle Aves., Brooklyn). In the background is the Williamsburg Bridge, (extending from Delancey Street, Manhattan to the Williamsburg Section of Brooklyn). June 12, 1931. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, another view. June 12, 1931. P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, not showing the Williamsburg Bridge. June 12, 1931. P. L. Sperr.

title: General view - Centre Street - Northwest.

text:
A general view northeastward from atop the Municipal Building at Park Row and Centre Street, showing the lower East Side area lying between the Bowery and the East River. The photographer is viewing towards the inlet on the Brooklyn Shore where the United States Navy Yard lies between the Manhattan and the Williamsburg Bridges. Note in View 2, the newly constructed slum clearance development, Knickerbocker Village.

May 3, 1932
View 2: July 18, 1934

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Christopher Street - Northeast. [Manhattan: Park Row - Centre Street ; 45 Christopher Street.]

text:
A general view northeastward from atop the Municipal Building at Park Row and Centre Street, showing the lower East Side area lying between the Bowery and the East River. The photographer is viewing towards the inlet on the Brooklyn Shore where the United States Navy Yard lies between the Manhattan and the Williamsburg Bridges. May 3, 1932
View 2: July 18, 1934

title: General view - Christopher Street - Northeast. [Manhattan: Park Row - Centre Street ; 45 Christopher Street.]

text:
A general view northeastward from atop the Municipal Building at Park Row and Center Streets, showing the lower East Side area lying in a bend of the East River. The photographer is viewing towards the inlet on the Brooklyn shore where the United States Navy Yard is. Bisecting the foreground is the South Ferry division of the Second and Third Avenues "E1"; that to the left leads to City Hall and the Brooklyn Bridge station (bridge on right of No. 3). In the center is the Manhattan Bridge and beyond the Williamsburg Bridge. Note the absence of Knickerbocker Village which will appear in 1934.

May 3, 1932
Views 1, 2 and 3

P. L. Sperr

title: General view - Centre Street - Northeast.

text:
Nassau Street, east side, north from but not including Spruce, to and including Frankfort Streets. Also shown is Park Row, east side, north from Spruce Street, to and including the Brooklyn Bridge Approach, (near North William Street). The view shows the Pulitzer (World) Building adjoining the Bridge Approach, with a statue of Benjamin Franklin in the foreground at the intersection of Nassau Street and Park Row.

June 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Park Row, east side, south from and including Spruce Street, to but not including Broadway. Also shown is Nassau Street, west side, south from and including Spruce Street. The view is taken from the Municipal Building, and shows a portion of City Hall Park in the foreground.

June 23, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Park Row - Spruce Street

text:
Park Row, east side, at Spruce Street, as seen across City Hall Park. The view shows a portion of the General Post Office on the right.

June 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

All buildings in view, except P.O., still extant - 1966!
title: Manhattan: Park Row - Spruce Street

text:
A general view, southwest from the Municipal Building at the intersection of Park Row and Centre Street, showing at the extreme right, the tower of the Singer Building, (Broadway at the N.W. corner of Liberty Street).

June 23, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: General view - Centre Street - Southwest.

text:
(1) A general view, south from the Municipal Building, at the intersection of Park Row and Centre Street, showing on the extreme left, the New York Telephone Building, (140 West Street, from Vesey to Barclay Streets), and in the centre, is the Singer Building, (Broadway, at the N.W. corner of Liberty Street). June 23, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from a different angle.

P. L. Sperr.

title: General view - Centre Street - South.

text:
(1)

A general view southwestward from the Municipal Building, at the junction of Centre Street and Park Row, showing (right to left) the Woolworth Building, on Broadway, west side, between Barclay Street and Park Place, and the Transportation Building, at the S.W. corner of Broadway and Barclay Street. In the foreground (left) appears the old U.S. Post Office on Mail Street, from Broadway to Park Row.

August 21, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

A view further westward from the Municipal Building, looking across the roof-top of the Court House, and showing (foreground) Broadway from Chambers (right) to Murray (left) Streets after crossing Warren Street. Also shown is the Hudson River and the French liner Normandie proceeding towards the Bay on its voyage to Europe. The New Jersey shore is visible in the far background. On the extreme left appears the major portion of the N.Y. Telephone Building (Washington Street).

August 21, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
title: General view - Centre Street - Southwest.

text:
(1)

title: General view - Centre Street - Southwest.

text:
A general view northwestward (in No. 1) and northward (in No. 2) from atop the Municipal Building at Park Row and Center Street. The first view shows business area lying between Broadway and the North (Hudson) River. Upon the latter and silhouetted against the Jersey shore is the S. S. "Normandie". View No. 2 is northward up Centre Street and shows in the foreground several civic buildings including the Tombs and the Criminal Courts Building. At the right margin is a part of the recently erected Federal Courts Building. In the background are skyscrapers constituting the midtown business zone.

August 21, 1935
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - [Manhattan] - Centre Street - Park Row - Municipal Building.

text:

The first view shows business area lying between Broadway and the North (Hudson) River. Upon the latter and silhouetted against the Jersey shore is the S. S. "Normandie". View No. 2 is northward up Centre Street and shows in the foreground several civic buildings including the Tombs and the Criminal Courts Building. Views 1 and 2

title: General view - [Manhattan] - Centre Street - Park Row - Municipal Building.

text:
Centre Street, at Park Row, showing prominently the Municipal Building and the Manhattan Approach to the Brooklyn Bridge. In the foreground appears the northeastern corner of City Hall Park with the Hall of Records opposite (left foreground). Across the East River looms the Brooklyn shore.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
title: Manhattan: Centre Street - Park Row

text:
A general view southwestward from the Municipal Building (convergence of Centre Street and Park Row), showing the upper portions of the Transportation and the Woolworth Buildings (left); the unfinished, new U.S. Post Office Building (center) and the N.Y. Telephone Building (with flag); all silhouetted against the North River and the New Jersey shore. About 1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad, A.R.P.S.
title: General view - [Manhattan] - Centre Street - Park Row - Municipal Building.
General view - [Manhattan - Convergence of Centre Street and Park Row] - Municipal Building.

text:
166 Nassau Street, Manhattan.
Tammany Hall
